answers.answer: First be sure you are under the care of a Eye MD ophthalmologist and that you have your peripheral vision checked regularily.You should not expect much improvement in your loss of peripheral vision, however it should not worsen unless you have another stroke.To prevent that talk to your doctor about control of blood pressure, keeping your cholesterol low, avoid being overweight or obese, treat any diabetes that is present, take your medicines, keep your appointments and DO NOT SMOKE.JCH III MD

question: On January 9, 2007 I had a light stroke.  Being only sixty-two years old I met with my pp and then onto my eye care specialist.  I was sent for an MRI of the brain within two days.  The neurologist told me I had had a stroke and had had several small strokes before.  I have lost the perifial vision in both of my eys. on the right sides of each.  Will this condition worsen in time?  I know my eye doctor, after taking a test, told me that I was close to failing it.  If it got worse I wouldn't beable to drive.  I have recognized that I have lost some short term memory.  This scares me.  Is there anything I can do?Thank you for your time.
title: Perifial Vision
